com.robix.nexway.event
Class PodEventGen

java.lang.Object
  com.robix.nexway.event.PodEventGen
public class PodEventGen
extends java.lang.Object

Helper class which generates events for changed Pod data.

This class is a helper for PodShoppingLists. PodEventGens refresh a shopping list, iterate over the updated data, and fire events to interested listeners.

PodEventGens are not driven by an internal thread. Client code must periodically "press the button" (call refreshXxx()), which updates the shopping list and fires events. This lets client code control the thread context of listener callbacks.

Below is an example of how a Swing application might periodically generate events using a Swing Timer. Application writers might also consider using a java.util.Timer or a separate Thread to refresh a PodEventGen. 

 import javax.swing.event.*;
 import com.robix.nexway.*;
 import com.robix.nexway.event.*;

 public class SensorMonitor
 {
    PodEventGen peg;
    javax.swing.Timer pegTimer;

    ...

    public void startMonitoring( Pod pod )
    {
       peg = pod.getDefaultPodEventGen();

       peg.addSensorListener( new SensorListener()
       {
          public void sensorChanged( SensorEvent e )
          {
             int id = e.getSensorId();
             int val = e.getSensorValue();

             System.out.println( "Sensor changed: id=" + id + "value=" + val );
          }
       } );

       pegTimer = new javax.swing.Timer( 250, new ActionListener()
       {
          public void actionPerformed( ActionEvent e )
          {
             peg.refresh();
          }
       } );

       pegTimer.start();
    }
 }
You can use the Usbor Nexway application to get an idea of how/when some Pod scripting events are generated. The "Pod Event Log" panel is very helpful in this regard. The Pod Event panel is not visible by default, so you'll have to add it to your PodGui. Right-click on the main scripting panel and select: Split This Panel -> Down. Then right-click on the new empty panel and select: Replace With -> Pod Event Log. Now when you execute scripts, you'll see a log of scripting events as they occur.

IMPORTANT:
In order to reduce object creation, event objects are re-used by the event generator. Listeners should not cache event objects between event notifications because the data stored in the event may change.

See Also:
Pod.getDefaultPodEventGen()

refreshScriptingInfo

public void refreshScriptingInfo()

refresh

public void refresh()
Refresh all pod data and fire events. Calling this method is the same as calling: 
  refreshServos();
  refreshDigouts();
  refreshSensors();
  refreshScriptingInfo();
